abstract: pmc BMC Musculoskelet Disord BMC Musculoskelet Disord 46 bmcmudis BMC Musculoskeletal Disorders 1471-2474 BMC PMC12487136 PMC12487136.1 12487136 12487136 41034770 10.1186/s12891-025-09185-8 9185 1 Research Comparative analysis of surgically treated degenerative cervical and lumbar spine diseases using multiple clinical aging indices Kurihara Ryosuke 1 Akaike Yuki 1 2 Michikawa Takehiro 3 Tobe Takao 4 Tobe Risa 5 Kawabata Soya 1 Nagai Sota 1 Imai Takaya 1 Takeda Hiroki 6 Kaneko Shinjiro 6 Yamada Shigeki 4 5 Fujita Nobuyuki nfujita2007@gmail.com 1 7 1 https://ror.org/046f6cx68 grid.256115.4 0000 0004 1761 798X Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, School of Medicine, Fujita Health University, 2 https://ror.org/02kn6nx58 grid.26091.3c 0000 0004 1936 9959 Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Keio University School of Medicine, 3 https://ror.org/02hcx7n63 grid.265050.4 0000 0000 9290 9879 Department of Environmental and Occupational Health, School of Medicine, Toho University, 4 https://ror.org/046f6cx68 grid.256115.4 0000 0004 1761 798X Department of Pharmacotherapeutics and Informatics School of Medicine, Fujita Health University, 5 https://ror.org/02r3zks97 grid.471500.7 0000 0004 0649 1576 Department of Clinical Pharmacy, Fujita Health University Hospital, 6 https://ror.org/046f6cx68 grid.256115.4 0000 0004 1761 798X Department of Spine and Spinal Cord Surgery, School of Medicine, Fujita Health University, 7 https://ror.org/046f6cx68 grid.256115.4 0000 0004 1761 798X Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Fujita Health University, 1 10 2025 2025 26 478161 902 5 7 2024 3 9 2025 01 10 2025 02 10 2025 03 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Background The prevalence of degenerative spine diseases has continued to rise with the aging of the global population. Despite the availability of various aging indices, limited studies have comprehensively investigated degenerative spine diseases from the perspective of aging. This study aimed to evaluate degenerative cervical and lumbar diseases surgically treated using multiple clinical aging indices and elucidate the characteristics of each condition through comparative analysis. Methods Clinical data of consecutive patients aged ≥ 65 years who underwent surgery for degenerative cervical and lumbar diseases were retrospectively collected. Frailty was assessed using the 11-point modified frailty index. Locomotive syndrome stage was determined based on the 25-Question Geriatric Locomotive Function Scale. Functional decline was assessed according to the Kihon Checklist. Polypharmacy was defined based on a cutoff of six drugs. A total of 19 categories were considered potentially inappropriate medications. Results Among the included patients, 313 and 103 had degenerative lumbar (L group) and degenerative cervical (C group) diseases, respectively. The C group had significantly lower serum albumin levels ( p p p p p p p p Conclusions Across various indices of aging, patients with degenerative cervical spine disease showed more significant progression than those with lumbar spine disease. Thorough understanding of these characteristics is essential when managing degenerative spine diseases, particularly in the selection of effective treatment approaches for the increasingly aging society in the future. Supplementary Information The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12891-025-09185-8. Keywords Frailty Locomotive syndrome Polypharmacy Potentially inappropriate medication Degenerative spine disease pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025 Background With the aging of the global population, the prevalence of degenerative spine diseases has continued to rise [ 1 3 4 7 4 8 9 5 6 4 Frailty and sarcopenia are commonly used as clinical indices of aging among older adults [ 10 11 12 13 13 14 15 16 17 Methods Subjects Clinical data of consecutive patients aged ≥ 65 years who underwent surgery for degenerative cervical and lumbar spine diseases at a single acute care hospital between April 2020 and May 2023 were retrospectively collected. Those who underwent surgery for spinal deformity and ossification of posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL) were excluded (Fig. 1 Ethics approval and consent to participate This study was approved by the institutional ethics committee. Informed consent was obtained through the opt-out method. All study methods were conducted in accordance with the principles stated in the Declaration of Helsinki.  Fig. 1 Flowchart of this study Data acquisition The following data were retrieved for analysis: age; body mass index (BMI); sex; medical history (e.g., hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes, stroke, cardiovascular disease, and cancer); preoperatively prescribed drugs; preoperative American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status; and serum albumin levels. Functional impairment Decline in physical function, nutrition, oral function, ADLs, memory, and mood were determined based on responses to 10 questions extracted from the Kihon Checklist upon admission [ 18 Frailty Frailty was assessed using the 11-point mFI, which examines 11 factors derived from the patient’s medical records. This index was used to classify our patients into three categories: robust, score = 0; prefrailty, score < 0.21; and frailty, score >0.21 [ 19 Locomotive syndrome Locomotive syndrome stage was determined based on the total GLFS-25 score: stage 0, score ≤ 6; stage 1, score ≥ 7; stage 2, score ≥ 16; and stage 3, score ≥ 24 [ 20 Polypharmacy and PIMs Polypharmacy was defined based on a cutoff of six drugs [ 21 17 Statistical analysis Data for the two groups were compared using Student’s t-test, Fisher’s exact test, or the Mann–Whitney U test, as appropriate. To assess longitudinal changes in locomotive syndrome stage, the McNemar Bowker test was used. Statistical analyses were performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (version 29.0; IBM Inc., Armonk, NY, United States), with p values of <0.05 indicating a statistically significant difference. Results A total 313 and 103 cases with degenerative lumbar spine diseases (L group) and degenerative cervical spine diseases (C group) were analyzed, respectively (Fig. 1 1 p p p p p p 2 p 2 p p p (26.2%) 0.27 Polypharmacy 218 (69.4%) 65 (63.1%) 0.23 Fisher`s exact test NSAIDs N/A Discussion The current study has been the first to comprehensively compare geriatric parameters among patients who underwent surgery for degenerative cervical and lumbar spine diseases. Our results indicate that cervical spine diseases were associated with more advanced frailty compared to lumbar spine diseases. Although no significant differences in locomotive syndrome stages were noted between the two conditions before surgery, postoperative improvement in locomotive syndrome was significantly poorer among those with cervical spine diseases. A comparison of the medical history revealed a significant difference in the frequency of dyslipidemia between the two groups. Moreover, patients with lumbar spine diseases tended to have a higher BMI than those with cervical spine diseases, albeit not significantly, as well as a significantly higher prevalence of dyslipidemia, suggesting a more pronounced metabolic component in the former. These findings are corresponded with previous studies documenting an association between degenerative lumbar disease and lifestyle-related diseases [ 22 24 18 25 26 Although the current study only used the GLFS-25 to assess locomotive syndrome, the preoperative distribution of locomotive syndrome stage observed herein corresponded well with those presented in previous reports for both cervical and lumbar spine diseases [ 27 28 25 27 27 29 30 From the perspective of medication prescription, no significant difference in the frequency of polypharmacy was observed between the two diseases. Among the PIMs frequently prescribed for the two conditions, the reason for the significantly higher frequency of diuretic use in cervical spine disease remains completely unclear. Considering report suggesting increased frequency of diuretic use among frail patients [ 31 17 3 8 The current study has several limitations. First, the subjects of this study were limited to surgical patients. Given that more cases receive conservative therapy than surgery for both conditions, this study cannot fully elucidate the characteristics of the two diseases. Second, the follow-up duration was only 1 year. Although it would have been preferable to observe outcomes for at least 2 years, a longer evaluation period may increase the difficultly of assessing the impact of surgery alone in clinical studies involving older patients. Third, the relatively high comorbidity rates reported for cervical and lumbar spine diseases suggest that our study population may have included patients suffering from both conditions, making the distinct differentiation between the two diseases challenging [ 32 Conclusions In conclusion, our comparison between cervical and lumbar spine diseases revealed that those with cervical spine disease exhibited more pronounced elements of frailty. Moreover, no significant differences in locomotive syndrome stages were observed between the two groups before surgery; however, those with cervical spine disease experienced inferior postoperative improvement in locomotive syndrome stage, resulting in a significantly more advanced postoperative locomotive syndrome stage among these patients. Taken together, our findings showed that patients with degenerative cervical spine diseases showed more significant progression than those with lumbar spine disease across various indices of aging. Thorough understanding of these characteristics is essential when managing degenerative spine diseases, particularly with regard to the selection of effective treatment approaches. Data availability The datasets generated and/or analyzed during the current study are not publicly available due to the limitations of ethical approval involving patient data and anonymity; however, they are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request. Declarations Ethics approval and consent to participate This research was approved by the Fujita Health University Ethics Committee (approval no. HM 23–354). Informed consent was waived by the Fujita Health University Ethics Committee. The Fujita Health University Ethics Committee also approved our use of the opt-out method for obtaining consent, indicating that all eligible patients were included in the present study unless they contacted us to opt out.
